data.title: Great Local Place
data.text: Great food, great service, very comfortable seating.  Local hang out for college kids and centrally located.

data.title: A Downtown Eatery Institution
data.text: Andy has been provided top drawer food for 3 decades.  Never has he faltered on serving the best dishes in tallahassee.

data.title: Great lunch spot for locals and visitors to the capitol city. Recommended by a local.
data.text: Sitting inside or out at Andrew's brings the lunch customer into the heart of state leaders, lobbyists, jurists, and employees from all three branches of government who can walk across the street from the capitol for a quick lunch. The lunch menu includes a bit of humor by naming the sandwich and salad fare after various people known in capitol circles; the names change regularly. The salads and sandwiches are always good, and the service is as well.

data.title: over priced and disappointing, at best...
data.text: I have lived in Tallahassee for 33 years, and this is the 2nd time I've eaten at Andrews.  Food was over priced and over rated.  Chicken was tough and breading was thick and chewy; very little bacon, had the Bondi club salad, should have been $10.00, as it was only a salad, probably 10 (maybe) pieces of meat, tabs. of bacon, teas. of shredded cheese, 6 tomato pieces, and a mound of lettuce....disappointing at best for $13.95!   It is cute that most of their food is named for some politician but make the menu very confusing for my international dining guest.

data.title: Good food in downtown Tallahassee
data.text: Nice place for brunch, lunch and dinner.  Good food and attentive service.  Nice Sunday brunch with generous assortment of dishes to select.

data.title: Gourmet!
data.text: I love everything about this restaurant. The location is so cool, the wait staff is so friendly and kind, and the food is always delicious. What's not to love?

data.title: Trying to be fancy
data.text: Not sure what this place is about. Food is overly complicated and a little pricey. And it's next to (and part of) a college bar. They had a nice wine list, I'll give them that, and it was interesting people watching.

owner_response.author: Andy R, Owner at Andrew's 228, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Thank you for taking the time to write us a review and provide feedback from your recent visit to Andrew's 228. We are sorry to hear your visit feel short and you did not enjoy your experience. If you could tell us what you found lacking in your visit we would greatly appreciate it. Please email us at hbernier@andrewsdowntown.com, we would love to hear for you so we can better our guest experience.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Popular with the Capital crowd, but food disappoints.
data.text: Andrew's is an extremely popular spot near the courthouse with a good Capital area location. My associate and I found our meals terribly disappointing. I had the Cubano sandwich with ordinary fries. The sandwich was huge and overstuffed with pork that was overcooked and dry. We both found the sweet tea undrinkable....way too sweet. My associate ordered a cajun styled pasta that prevented him from completing a sentence as it was so hot he could not speak! Not that many choices in this part of town, but do yourself a favor and try.

owner_response.author: Andy R, Owner at Andrew's 228, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Hi James, thank you for taking the time to write a review and provide us with feedback. We’re disappointed to learn that you found the pork in your sandwich to be lacking in tenderness and your tea to be on the sweet side, as we certainly try to impress our guests with perfectly cooked proteins and delicious southern tea. While we always encourage our guests to bring any issue they may have with a menu item to our attention so we can have the opportunity to alter any dish to your personal liking, we appreciate your comments and do hope you’ll consider giving us another shot in the future.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: A fixturen Tallahassee downtown history
data.text: I have been to Andrews many times over the past 20+ years .Always a good experience,the food and service,consistent and excellent. If you want to invite anyone,a couple or a group ,you won't go wrong at all.

data.title: Love the location
data.text: This is a nice spot downtown. The food selection is great. I love their pastas and the buffalo chicken dip as a starter is so good. The staff is always prompt and friendly.

data.title: Great downtown restaurant
data.text: Had dinner with friends here at andrews. The seafood entre was very good. Wines available with a varied selection.

data.title: Good food, bad service!
data.text: A group of business associates decided to have lunch at Andrews.  The food was good when we finally got it but one in our party almost passed out because the wait was extremely lengthy.  When I brought it to the managers attention he couldn't have cared less.  Guess it pays to have a captive audience what with being so close to the capital.

data.title: Great special occasion venue
data.text: Went here on a Friday night after happy hour showed up an hour later than our reservation and they were still nice enough to seat us. The restaurant is underground warm and cozy and beautiful ,the food was good ,the portions are huge.easy to find location but beware, you are in the middle of college student happy hour bedlam

data.title: The best in Tallahassee
data.text:
If you're used to places with great food (Chicago, NYC, New Orleans, Miami) or even better than average food (Atlanta, Orlando, Las Vegas, Charlotte), You'll be pretty sad in Tallahassee. To be fair its a college town, but its also the state capital so you'd expect at least a few kind of fine dining places. Anyway, no. 
Andrews 228 is the place. Years ago when I went to school in Tallahassee in the 90's, Andrews down stairs was really special. It was formal. The waiters wore jackets and the food was classic but very good. Now its more casual. The food is ok, not amazing but definitely the best you'll get in Tallahassee.

data.title: Great Overall
data.text:
Had dinner here with my sisters.  We started with a cheese board that offered a wonderful variety of cheeses, fruit and nuts.  Nice way to begin our dinner.  Cocktails were made well and service was spectacular.  Our entrees were wonderful.  

Good place to go with friends or family or for a business meal.

data.title: Perfect Place for a special evening
data.text: This is the perfect place for a special event in your lives.   Anniversary, Valentine's day, recent promotion, any time you want the evening to be special Andrew's 228 is the place.  They always go out for you.  Quiet and intimate your special person (s) will be impressed.

data.title: Great Food!
data.text: This is a very cozy location, hidden in the downtown Tallahassee region.  The food was great.  I will definitely visit this restaurant again.

data.title: Service and Atmosphere get a A++++
data.text: This place has fantastic food, drinks, and service. It's down in a cellar, which makes it different. Very cozy. Worth the visit!!!

data.title: You know those places ........
data.text:
You know those places that have been around for a while and have a reputation for being fantastic? The places that are a bit pricey (nothing completely outrageous) and somewhere you would probably want to dress up a little for? The places that exemplify "downtown dining"?

Andrew's 228 is one of a handful of places like this that Tallahassee has to offer. (To be honest, Tallahassee doesn't offer much to begin with).

Anyways, my wife and I had dinner here last night. Here is how it went:

Parking was a bit of a worry, through no fault of Andrew's 228. We suffered brain flatulence and forgot that our reservations for dinner were around the time of the Downtown Get-Down. The price of parking at Kleman Plaza was jacked up and the garage was filling fast.

What should have been a pleasant stroll to Andrew's a couple blocks away ended up being a feat in navigating through a sea of stupidity. There are times that you just want to yell out "get out of my way", but common sense kicks in as you realize that doing so in a crowd of a bunch of drunks and college kids (sometimes one-in-the-same) would be a terrible idea. 

The sea of idiots got worse right next to Andrew's 228 ... where Andrew's Capital Bar and Grill is (right next door to 228).

None of this is through Andrew's fault ... just know that things are going to be a little crazy here if you come on certain Fridays during college football season.

Inside, however, was another matter. It was nice and quiet (in other words, hardly anyone was there). We probably didn't even need to have reservations, but just so you know, they do take reservations (unlike MOST restaurants in Tallahassee that either have never allowed reservations or have phased out the practice of reservations to this call-ahead waiting malarkey).

We were promptly seated. The restaurant looked nice and more up-to-date than not (unlike Georgio's, which looks like it fell through a time warp from the 80's). The service was pleasant; the hostess was polite and friendly, and the waiter was very nice ... checking on our table an appropriate amount of times (not too little and not too much ... and there is a such thing as too much).

We started with drinks ... the wife had water (typical), and I had a water and an adult beverage "Bananas Foster" ... flavored much like the dessert. The drink was actually a decent value. Most places would charge more for their cocktails.

We ordered an appetizer ... bacon-wrapped scallops. They tasted good (and were presented nicely), however I am really glad there were no more in our party than just my wife and I. When the appetizer got to the table, there were only 3 scallops (and the little half-dollar sized pancake that came with it) on the plate. We thought the price of the appetizer was pretty fair WHEN WE ORDERED IT; however, I would argue that the value changed once we received it at the table. At least we had the complimentary bread (very good by the way, and sports a variety of breads) to keep us busy.

Next up, entrees. The wife had the dijon brie chicken, while I had the bronzed snapper. Both entrees came with smashed potatoes. From what I tasted of her meal, it was pretty good. The dijon sauce had great flavor to it. As for my snapper, it was decent. Sadly, most of the flavor on my plate came from the squash noodles. The whole dish was screaming for salt; however, there was no salt to be seen on the table. The was a pepper mill, but no salt shaker.

I know a lot of places want to limit salt consumption. I can make that decision for myself, thank you very much. Especially in a state like Florida, where it seems that more and more restaurants cook their food as bland as can be in order to please senior citizens that have dietary restrictions. I am not a senior citizen; I can still have seasoned food. 

As you can tell, this is my biggest gripe with our meal / experience. I probably could have asked for salt, and they may have brought some out (though I have been to some places that wouldn't), but I shouldn't have to. Salt should be on the table. It isn't an insult to your chef if the food isn't seasoned to my personal liking. However, it IS an insult to me as a paying customer to have something so simple as salting my food taken away from me.

Stepping down from the soapbox ....

After the entrees, we (I) ordered a dessert: their bread pudding. It was a pumpkin and white chocolate bread pudding. Easily the best part of the meal. Came with (cinnamon, I believe) ice cream.

Overall, nice atmosphere, quiet, food is good (not great) and pleasant staff. Only bad part was the NO SALT part.

data.title: Great find
data.text: This establishment was very accomodating for a large party - 14!.  All those around me enjoyed a variety of entrees - pulled pork sandwich, wrap, I had an excellent salad. Staff was polite and helpful
